You can’t have enough players with pace.“He’s played No  as well and he fits the bill in terms of the type of player we want to bring to the club.”Despite the club’s immediate future unclear as they battle relegation from the Premiership, that’s not stopped Jim putting preparations in place.In the immediate future, however, is Hearts on Saturday at Dens Park.Jim was at Firhill on Monday night to watch the Jambos draw - with Partick in the Scottish Cup and is hopeful his side can repeat their - success at Tynecastle last month.He added: “We had a really good result against them last time.“They’ve had a wee sticky period with injuries but we know we’ll have to defend better than we have because we will be tested.“I always feel we have a chance of winning games, especiallywe can get our strikers fit and, with the wide players we have, I feel we are always going to create.”

title: dundee owners make fresh bid to supporters society to increase shares
story: Dundee FC’s owners have made a fresh bid to boost their control in the club to over %.The Tele revealed in January that Football Partners Scotland , the majority shareholder owned by Tim Keyes, had made a move to buy the ‘A’ Ordinary shares owned by the Dundee Football Club Supporters Society.With those came rights of veto regarding a range of issues including a stadium share or potential merger with another club.That was knocked back by the Society and now Dundee finance director David Gray has written to them in an attempt to buy their Ordinary shares to bring FPS’ holding to .%.This would allow them to claim Group Tax Relief to offset losses made by the club. A deadline of March  has been made by the club for the Society to decide on two proposals put forward by Dundee FC.The first would see FPS buy the Ordinary shares for £,, the club’s preferred option. These shares have a nominal value, at  pence per share, of £,.The second is for DFCSS to “agree to support resolutions which increase the club’s share capital and then allot shares specically to FPS”.Currently there is no provision in the Society’s rules to sell shares and an extraordinary general meeting would be needed to change that, and with it a vote by its members.The Financial Conduct Authority would also need to be contacted, a process which could take months.DFCSS already had a board meeting scheduled for next Tuesday and will discuss the proposals and their response as a board as well as with their members, despite the sharp time constraint.In a statement, the club added: “At a time when our primary focus is on retaining our Premiership status, we would prefer not to have to undertake an unnecessary time consuming and expensive full share issue and we hope that the Society will support us in agreeing to one of the suggested options.”

title: dundee skipper martin woods says side need to keep their heads to avoid relegation
story: Martin Woods says Dundee need to keep their heads in the “crazy” Premiership run-in as they attempt to battle their way to safety.The Dark Blues dropped back into the relegation play-off place after a - thumping dished out by Rangers last Wednesday on the back of a - home defeat to Hibs.However, it was a surprise result at Pittodrie that saw Woods  Co. drop back down the league as Hamilton Accies defeated Aberdeen -, with Saturday also seeing St Mirren close the gap below to one point by defeating Livingston -.Woods, has captained the side recently in Josh Meekings# continued absence, said: “Hamilton was a real shock, I didn’t see that coming at all.“Coming in to hear that after the game was a blow but there will be lots of ups and downs between now and the end of the season, we just need to take care of our own business and, hopefully, that will be enough to steer us clear.“I don’t think anybody would have seen after their game against Rangers, Hamilton going up to Aberdeen and winning - but it’s a crazy league.“Weeks ago, nobody would have seen us going to Tynecastle and getting a result so there will be ups and downs and we have to stick together.“We’ve looked through the Rangers game and seen what we can do better defensively as a team and take that on to the next bunch of games to get some points on the board.”With no match over the weekend due to the Scottish Cup taking priority, it’s been a welcome break for the Dark Blues after a couple punishing results.Woods hopes the breather will allow them to up their game when Hearts come calling on Saturday.“I think it’s been a tough run of games so it’s been good to sit back, reflect and get ready to go again,” he added.“We’ll work on a few things in the training ground and take it into the next bunch of games which are going to be vital.“We have a couple of tough ones coming up with Hearts at home, which we hope to get something out of, and then Celtic at home will be a day we have to be disciplined and get off to a lot better start than we did at Rangers.”If they keep their discipline and manage to up their level from the first half at Ibrox, Woods is confident their luck will turn to help them make it two wins in a row against Hearts, after their - victory at Tynecastle in January.He added: “Against Livingston, they went down to  men, we got a goal in the last seven minutes, we could’ve had a penalty against us so we’ll get days where things go for you.“That’s probably two in a row where nothing’s gone for us at all against Hibs and Rangers.“There will be loads of twists and turns before now and the end of the season, we just need to focus on our performance levels and try to keep that high.“We dropped in the first half against Rangers which wasn’t great but that was a mixture of both them being really good and us not doing as well as we could.“The first goal from a set-piece, we weren’t tight enough and got punished.“From there you could see them get a lt and that’s an important thing to do at Ibrox, to start well.“It was very frustrating but we’ll not be judged by games like away at Ibrox, there will be a lot of big games to come before now and the end of the season.”Woods is also keen to repay the club’s support that has been starved of home success this season with the number of home wins the worst in the ision.“The fans have stuck with us and they were brilliant against Hibs.“I think they can see the performance level has been better in recent weeks.”

title: embrace title race pressure urges dundee uniteds reynolds
story: Mark Reynolds says the pressure is only going to increase on Dundee United as the season nears its end but he’s backed the Tangerines to embrace it by running down leaders Ross County.The Staggies have a five-point advantage on Reynolds  Co. going into United’s final  matches of the campaign and the on-loan Aberdeen man expects the intensity to increase game by game in the race to promotion.He said: “You need to embrace the pressure.“If you are in a team that’s got aspirations to go up and compete in the Premiership you need to deal with pressure.“There are players that don’t deal with that but they don’t play in big teams.“We have a good enough dressing-room and boys who want it and are used to playing under pressure in big games.“Everyone has the capability of thriving in it and that’s what we need to do.“We just need to keep on winning. Ross County will just keep doing what they do but the good thing is we play them twice so it can still be in our hands.“If we beat them in those games then it starts to put the pressure on but we still need them to slip up to make up the eight points.“We’ve left ourselves a lot to do but all we can do is win the games in front of us.“Regardless of who it is, every game will be huge and three points will be massive.”After the disappointment of losing Sunday’s Scottish Cup quarter-final against Inverness, United are targeting an immediateto their recent good league form with  points picked up from their last  available.They take on bottom side Partick Thistle this weekend at Firhill and Reynolds has urged the Terrors to “step up” and grab the three points.He added: “It was disappointing on Sunday and the boys were hurting – it’s right we feel that disappointment and let it sink in before getting back to training yesterday and then focus on the league.“We realise that was a chance to get in a semi-final but the next  games will be like cup finals.“There will be pressure, teams will try to stop us, they’ll make it horrible and we’ll be a scalp.“Teams will want to take points off us but we need to deal with that, step up and find ways to beat them.“If we keep winning then the pressure will increase and increase and it’ll get harder and harder but we need to deal with that.“We need to step up and,we do that, then we’ll have a good chance.”After a testing double header against Inverness Caley Thistle last week with a league win followed by that cup defeat, Reynolds expects the Highlanders to be a handful for their semi-final opponents – whether it’s this weekend’s opponents Partick or Premiership Hearts.He said: “Inverness are a big physical team – they put the ball up the park and play off the back of it and they have good players in amongst that.“Last Tuesday I thought we stood up to that and we won more balls, picked up more seconds and did enough to keep them out.“We didn’t do that on Sunday, we were second to too many balls.“Inverness can do that to teams. They will cause problems.”Reynolds, meanwhile, is happy to see no astroturf surfaces on the horizon after missing recent away trips to Queen of the South and Falkirk on physio’s orders.“That’s the last game on plastic pitches so, unless we go to the play-offs and have to play on one it’ll be fine.“It was just too early, that’s me not long back from a cruciate ligament injury so the advice from the physios was not to play on it and not risk it.“They were the guys that got me back so it would be daft not to listen to them.”

title: former dundee united defender harry souttar called into australian squad
story: Former Dundee United defender Harry Souttar has been called into the Australia U  squad.The -year-old, who is on loan at Fleetwood Town from current employers Stoke City, has accepted a call-up for Australia’s Olympic qualication squad for their training camp in Malaysia and qualiers in Cambodia.Souttar has already represented Scotland at U  and U  level and, along with brother John, is poised to be the first Scottish siblings to play for dferent countries.John made his international debut last year after Hearts boss Craig Levein warned Scotland risked losing him to Australia because he was eligible to play for the Socceroos.Harry had previously insisted it was his dream to play for Scotland.He#s eligible to play for Australia through his mother, who was born in Australia.He stressed two years ago during Scotland U ’s Elite Round qualiers in Czech Republic he was desperate to play for his country.He said: “My ambition has always been to play for Scotland. Who knows, maybe one day I will partner John at the centre of defence for Scotland.“My aim is to try to get myself established in English football and then see what happens.”But Socceroos boss Graham Arnold, who is also in charge of the U  side, insists he’s delighted to have persuaded the former Tangerines and Ross County stopper to follow in the footsteps of Hibs winger Martin Boyle and pledge their future for Australia.The Aussies were alerted to Souttar’s availability by his Stoke City team-mate Adam Federici.Arnold said: “When you look at Harry and his size, he is a beast. However, he is also very good on the ground, too, with his feet and we will take a good look at him.”

title: if they werent there already it is must win time for dark blues
story: Before I start, let me open my big book of cliches and get some of them out of the way.First off the bat, in defence of this piece, cliches are only cliches because they are, generally, true.And it is true that Dundee are about to enter a period of games, some of which are must-win, and most of which are must-not-lose, which could define their season.Before the Dark Blues enter into the post-split realm of six-pointers, though, they must navigate five more tough Premiership fixtures.They will be in for some real battlesthey are to pick up points but they have fighters in their squad now which will give the Dee hope they can do it.No one less so than manager Jim McIntyre. He has marshalled a slight upturn in fortunes in recent weeks which has only been offset by the improved form of their relegation rivals Hamilton Accies and St Mirren, also.However, for Macca, it won’t be job done until Dundee are mathematically safe.And that is a long way off, as they sit in the relegation play-off place, three points behind Accies and only one ahead of the Buddies.Tonight, the Tele takes a look at the Dark Blues’ run-in to the split to see where they can pick up much-needed points.Dundee v Hearts # Saturday, March One of Dundee’s four wins this season, and their only one against a team which currently occupies the top six, came at Tynecastle at the end of January.That - success in Gorgie, coupled with the Jambos’ recent struggles – they are without a win in their last four league outings – will give the Dark Blues confidence going into Saturday’s clash at Dens Park.However, the Dee have only won once at home all season and need that to changethey are to have any hopes of staying in the ision.It’s must-win, for me, and I think they will rise to the occasion.Verdict: Three points.Dundee v Celtic # Sunday, March A game in which Dundee will not be judged on come the end of the season but one,they keep it tight at the back, could see them sneak a valuable point.However, I fancy Celtic to go on a really good run as they look to wrap up eight titles in a row under new manager Neil Lennon.They’ll have too much.Verdict: No points.St Mirren v Dundee # Saturday, March One word. Ten letters. Hyphenated. Six-pointer.If the teams go into this one still practically neck and neck, which I expect they will, a win would be extremely valuable for both.However, I feel, with the enormity of the occasion, they will cancel each other out in Paisley.Verdict: One point.St Johnstone v Dundee # Wednesday, April The Dee and Saints have had some tasty encounters in recent seasons and this one should be no dferent with both teams likely to still have plenty to play for.St Johnstone may still be in the mix for the top six while Dundee’s situation is self-explanatory.I fancy the Dark Blues for this one, they play better on the road and have more to lose than the Perth men.Verdict: Three points.Dundee v Aberdeen # Saturday, April You have to go back to November  for the last time Dundee got a win of any sorts against the Dons.That’s a run of  games without a win, with  losses in a row.That run has to end at some point, so I’ll back the Dee for a hard-earned draw.Verdict: One point.Total points: Eight points.That would leave Dundee with  going into the split and, you would like to think, put them in a decent position to stay up. That is, depending on how Hamilton and St Mirren get on with their fixtures .Hamilton – Motherwell , Hearts , Kilmarnock , Livingston , St Mirren .Verdict: Five points.St Mirren – Kilmarnock , St Johnstone , Dundee , Celtic , Hamilton .Verdict: Eight points.That would leave Hamilton level and St Mirren a point behind Dundee.

title: we have to roll our sleeves up says dundee uniteds mark connolly
story: Mark Connolly says Dundee United have to “roll their sleeves up and deal with it” when met by a physical challenge like the one Inverness Caley Thistle brought on Sunday.But he’s urged his team-mates to get the ball down and play when they get the chance.The Highland outfit out-fought the Tangerines at Tannadice and deservedly booked their place in the last four of the Scottish Cup.A disappointment Connolly says United have to put behind them before facing Partick Thistle in a big league game this weekend.He said: “We weren’t ourselves on Sunday.“We didn’t really create as many chances as we have been recently.“Inverness are a very big team, physical – we dealt with it at times, other times we didn’t and we were utterly disappointed on Sunday night but we have to move on.“Of course we would have enjoyed a trip to Hampden, not just for the players but the football club and the fans, for everyone involved at the club.“However, now our target is to get to the top league and we have  games where we have to do as well as we can in all of them to push and get promoted.“Every game in this league is a tough game, physical and direct, but we need to roll our sleeves up and deal with it.“On the other hand, when we get the chance to play we need to play football.”

title: Campaigners press on with vision for Inverness park
story: CAMPAIGNERS hoping to transform a historic Inverness park into a vibrant green space are pressing on with their vision, despite suffering a setback.The Northern Meeting Park Group hopes to transfer ownership of the venue in Ardross Street from Highland Council to a community-run organisation in a bid to enable greater public access and breathe new le into its dilapidated buildingsBut its application for a pound, grant to prepare a business plan and carry out surveys has been turned down by the Scottish Land Fund.Following feedback, however, it is now preparing to submit another application in May and is hoping for more positive news.It is also planning to open the usually locked park gates to the public for one week at Easter and another week in the school summer holidays.It is a repeat of a successful two-week trial opening last summer when hundreds took up the chance to enjoy the space for ious uses including family outings, outdoor office meetings and picnic lunches.Leading campaigner Jon Ford hopes to encourage greater use and activities during the opening weeks taking place April ndash and July ndash.ldquoThis year, we also want people to let us knowthey want to form a programme of events and we can seeit is something we can put on, he said.ldquoIf people are out and about in the park there might be a shinty game going on, for example, or a pipe band.Another possibility might be a Teddy bearsrsquo picnic.The group is also in talks with the Care and Learning Allianceabout future possibilities to use the location for childcare provision .In addition, discussions have taken place with the Calman Trust a young peoplersquos service offering housing support, training, employment opportunities, cooking services, about serving refreshments.Jaci Douglas, Calarsquos chief executive, said during discussions with the community over a year ago, flexible and accessible childcare was identied as one of the needs in the area along with a possible use for the park space.ldquoWe have been working closely with the Northern Meeting Park Group on how best to meet that aspiration, she said.ldquoAs an early years charity, Cala is well placed to work with partners to provide a quality early learning and childcare service and we are really excited about the opportunity to do that in close collaboration with the community group, Highland Council and Highland Le Highland as well as with local parents although itrsquos still at the early planning stages. ldquoThursday  Mar  : PM

title: Candlelight tribute for Highland musician
story: A SOPRANO singer has paid tribute to her ldquospecial friend who inspired her to perform a candlelit concert to raise pound for a cancer care charity.Liz McLardy laid on an evening of music and song for Maggiersquos Highlands to show her admiration to staff who lted the spirits of her close friend Helen Sproston in the final days of her le.Mrs Sproston, a -year-old artist and musician who played alto saxophone in the Bonny Vista Social Club, and the Highland Swing band, would have been parted from her beloved Tibetan terrier called Mac had Maggiersquos not allowed friends to bring the dog in for visits while she was being treated at neighbouring Raigmore Hospital.The concert, called Baroque by Candlelight, in which Ms McLardy performed with pianist Tonya Clement and James Ross on clarinet, was held at St Johnrsquos Church in Inverness on February .Poignantly, Mrs Sproston passed away on the same day.Ms McLardy said: ldquoHelen was special. She was just so full of le. She did all sorts of outrageous things like climbing Mont Blanc and she travelled a lot.ldquoShe was a good artist and musician and she loved her little dog. She was unique. Yoursquod never have believed she was in her seventies.Mrs Sprostonrsquos ex-sister-in-law Kay Hall, with whom she attended Altrincham Grammar School in Cheshire, and had held a close bond as the pair married twin brothers, said Mrs Sproston has a son, Stuart, who lives in Barcelona. Her late husband Ron died several years ago.Paying her own tribute, she said: ldquoHelen was a free spirit and a very determined woman. Some people would say she was stubborn and that helped with the diagnosis. She was determined to make best use of the time that she had left.Bonny Vista Social Club guitarist Pete Gavin said he enjoyed Helenrsquos ldquohard-wit and her stoic approach to living and dying.He said: ldquoA couple of us in the band are aware of our own mortality for ious reasons and Helen was a good example for us because her attitude was very much like lsquoitrsquos time for the last song and Irsquom okay with thatrsquo.Fellow band members made a music recording for her, which she wanted to be played at her funeral.She also recorded a few final words which were edited into the track, thanking friends for all their love and good wishes and paying special thanks to the exceptional buddy who ldquosneaked in the GTs during visits.Then the music fades out with her laughter, Helenrsquos parting gt.Thursday  Mar  : PM

title: Date set for Highland air traffic controllers strike
story: Air traffic controllers working for Highlands and Islands Airport Limitedare set to strike on April , affecting operations at Inverness Airport as well as in Dundee, Wick, Kirkwall, Sumburgh, Stornoway and Benbecula.Members of the Prospect union will also take action short of a strike between April and August , in a continuing disagreement over their pay offer for -.This will include instruction to work to rosters an overtime ban and withdrawal of goodwill though Prospect says it will seek to agree a protocol with Hial to ensure cover for emergency incidents.David Avery, Prospect negotiations officer, said: ldquoProspect members have agreed to delay any strike action until after the Scottish school holidays have concluded."Our members do not want to stop their friends and neighbours visiting their families during the school holidays.ldquoI urge Hial and Scottish ministers to use the additional time members have given them to bring forward real proposals to resolve the dispute rather than the same offer which has already been rejected twice.Thursday  Mar  : PM

title: Demolition of Eastgate Hostel to start soon
story: EVERY effort will be made to keep disruption to a minimum during the long-awaited demolition of an eyesore in Inverness city centre.Work is set to begin on Monday to take down the scaffolding and frontage of the former Eastgate Hostel which has been a blot on the landscape since being gutted by a blaze in April .Inverness city centre manager David Haas said representatives from Highland Council and the Inverness Business Improvement District have been liaising with the agents to work out a programme to ensure the work happens with the least disruption.There would be a temporary narrowing of the thoroughfare to enable the work to be carried out as quickly and effectively as possibly.ldquoWe are working closely with the business community so they understand the need for the works and that we are taking steps to minimise the disruption so as not to prejudice theof their businesses, Mr Haas said.Businesses would still be able to welcome people through their doors.ldquoAs a member of the public you will be able to walk up and down unhindered, he stressed.Talks have also taken place to ensure access for emergency services and deliveries.ldquoEveryone will understand this is an important moment for the High Street and the city, he said. ldquoWe want to give the opportunity to take the building down as quickly and efficiently as possible.The demolition is expected to take  weeks. The plan is for each stone at the front to be marked and set aside for reuse in the rebuild which has now been approved.ldquoI am very pleased that at long last we are going to see activity which is positive and aon the High Street to a usable site in that area, Mr Haas said.ldquoWe are all conscious we have to maintain a proper service to the public. We will not lose sight of that.ldquoThe agents and the contractor are very committed to getting this job done to the highest professional standard.The demolition follows a long-running campaign by the Inverness Courier which ensured the story remained in the headlines.Thursday  Mar  : PM

title: Firms are urged to prepare for Brexit
story: BUSINESSES in the Highlands and Islands are not doing enough to prepare for the impact of Brexit, Highlands and Islands Enterprisehas warned.More than two-thirdsof firms who took part in the agencyrsquos latest business  survey in September and October highlighted Brexit as one the main risks they face, with only  per cent believing it posed no risk to their business.Despite this, the survey showed that only  per cent of firms have a plan in place to help them prepare for Brexit, and a fthrecognise that they need to develop a plan.Carroll Buxton, HIErsquos director of regional development, said: ldquoWhile there is still a great deal of uncertainty about how Brexit will affect businesses in the region, some are already taking steps to prepare, and we would encourage others to do so.ldquoThere is help available on the Prepare for Brexit website and from our own website. Through these, businesses can access expert advice to help them plan, including a handy -point Brexit checklist.More than a thirdof businesses that took part in the survey were trading internationally, but respondents had mixed views on the importance to their business of access to the European Single Market. Just over halfregarded this as important while  per cent said it is not important. However, a higher proportionconsidered the single market important to the Scottish economy overall.The free movement of people across the EU was also viewed as important to the Scottish economy by  per cent of respondents, yet only two in fivefelt it was important to their own business.In addition to questions on Brexit and international trade, the business  survey covered other core issues such as economic confidence, business performance and optimism.Almost two thirdssaid they were confident in the regionrsquos economy and  per cent were optimistic about their own performance and prospects.Thursday  Mar  : PM

title: Inverness College UHI lecturers on strike again
story: COLLEGE lecturers are on strike today after pay talks failed to produce any agreement.Members of the EIS Further Education Lecturersrsquo Association in Inverness have joined colleagues across Scotland in striking, with another strike set for March .It follows two one-day strikes earlier this year in pursuit of a cost of living pay increase.Picket lines were seen outside Inverness College UHI at Inverness Campus.Talks aimed at averting the strikes broke down without a resolution, leaving representatives for colleges exasperated, according to the Colleges Scotland Employersrsquo Association.John Gribben, the associationrsquos director of employment services, said: ldquoThe Scottish Government has made it clear that there is no more money for lecturersrsquo pay and colleges have to find the pay deal on offer by making cuts.ldquoIf there were any more money available, our priorities would be for additional investment in enhancing studentsrsquo experiences and on further improving college campuses.Thursday  Mar  : PM

title: Inverness West residents asked to give their views
story: People living in the Inverness West ward of Highland Council are being invited to take part in two consultation events focussing on the main objectives for the area.Feedback from a similar event last year will be provided and members of the community will be able to see what progress has been made on a range of priorities.Residentsrsquo views on the Riverside Way project, progress with pedestrian crossings over the A, parking and the forthcoming West Link Phase  are very welcome as are any other areas of interest in the ward.In addition there will be drawings and further information on the West Link Phase , with staff available to answer questions.Councillor Graham Ross said: ldquoWe had a great response last year to our ward priority list and members of the community engaged very constructively in telling us about dferent issues and concerns, and suggesting how problems can be tackled."We look forward to sharing the progress made and to hearing of any fresh priorities for the ward. I would encourage as many people as possible to take up this chance to get involved and come along to either of the sessions.Both drop-in sessions will take place on Wednesday, March .The first is from pm to pm at the Bught Stop and the next is from pm-pm in Charleston Academy.Thursday  Mar  : PM

title: Keep Safe scheme signs up new Highland sites
story: FRIGHTENED people seeking refuge now have more safe zones in which to get support in Nairn.Police Scotland and the I Am Me charity have welcomed new members to the arearsquos Keep Safe network, which gives people a place to gothey feel frightened, distressed or have been the victim of crime.Nairn Citizens Advice Bureau has joined the initiative, which is delivered in partnership between I Am Me and Police Scotland.The Keep Safe project aims to help people with a disability, feel safe within their community.I Am Me is a community partnership charity developed in Renfrewshire, to raise awareness of Disability Hate Crime.Gill Maclean, manager of Nairn Citizens Advice Bureau, said: ldquoWe are delighted to have been approved as a Keep Safe space and are keen to do all we can help vulnerable people feel safer and, therefore, more likely to venture out into the town.Inspector Judy Hill told the Courier: ldquoThis initiative aims to help vulnerable members of our communities, including the elderly and the disabled, to feel safe and know where to go for help and assistance should they require it.ldquoAll Keep Safe places are approved by Police Scotland.ldquoSometimes due to disability or age-related illness, people can easily become disorientated, lost or become confused, especially in and around unfamiliar surroundings.ldquoKeep Safe can offer a reassurance that there is somewhere people can seek assistancerequired.For more details about the scheme, go online at www.iammescotland keep-safe about-keep-safe Thursday  Mar  : PM

title: My Ness art is approved
story: Three residents and Balleary Community Council failed to meet the deadline, although the planners did consider the community councilrsquos objection despite it being late.The artwork, My Ness, was approved under delegated powers, much to the surprise of some city councillors. Delegated powers meant that the application, from Highland Council, was considered by officials and not elected councillors.My Ness is a curved wall sweeping up and over the water which can be used as a seat, a walkway or a viewing .The concerns of the community council and the three iniduals included the impact on wildle and habitats, the deep piling required and possible pollution during construction.Cllr Ken Gowans said: ldquoThis is very disappointing as there are many unanswered questions that that could have been addressed at the planning committee. There are still concerns regarding the future of the fishermanrsquos hut, erosion of the river bank and where the displaced water will go in high water conditions.Cllr Bill Boyd said some people were not behind My Ness, which was to replace the highly controversial tilting pier artwork earmarked for the riverbank at Eden Court until it was ditched two years ago after a public furore. He said there was a question mark over the future of Inverness Angling Clubrsquos hut currently on the site.Zosia Fraser, chairwoman of Balleary Community Council, said: ldquoI think the fair and democratic way of dealing with this would be in open debate.Thursday  Mar  : PM

title: New viewing platforms for Inverness riverside
story: A NEW series of "people perches" are to be installed along the River Ness to let people "engage" with the water ndash as a row continues over how plans for a more major piece of waterside art were approved.An artistrsquos impression shows the Rest Space to be sited in Bank Street, opposite the Mercure Hotel, as a set of steps leading to a fenced  over the river.One of several planned for theof the water it is currently in storage, with plans for its installation next month.Designed by Glasgow-based design practice Dress for the Weather it says on its website: "Rest Spaces is one of a series of art initiatives to encourage people to experience and engage with the river as it flows through the city.ldquoIt will encourage people to stop and enjoy the river in a iety of ways: to perch, to explore, to bask, to gather."Councillor Isabelle MacKenzie, chairwoman of the city of Inverness arts working group, which is overseeing the wide-ranging public art programme of which Rest Spaces is one part, said she thought it was ldquorather magnicent.Adding that, cumulatively, the artworks being created along the riverside would make walking in the area a more interesting experience she said: "There might well be some detractors but we are all iniduals."Councillor Ken Gowans, who was a vocal critic of the previous "tilting pier" proposals shelved several years ago, said he was more relaxed about the Bank Street installation."It will be in a very busy and popular location, especially with tourists, and I suspect it will add some interest to that part of the river," he said.Their remarks were made as other councillors continued to voice anger over revelations that the larger scale curving walls artwork proposed for a site close to the Ness Islands has been nodded through by planning officers rather than being put before elected members.Previously called The Gathering Place and My Ness, but referred to as My River Ness in the recently approved application, this artwork involves two crescent-shaped walls curving out from opposite sides of the river.Having been approved by officers under delegated powers councillors have reportedly been told there is now no way to call it in to the planning committeeNess-side SNP councillor Ron MacWilliam said he is set to meet with Inverness city centre manager David Haas over the issue and has called for a special meeting of the city of Inverness area committee."The natural urban environment is a key asset for Inverness and shouldnrsquot be degraded by development where it can be avoided," he said."The commitment by the previous council to spend on the original Gathering Place design, whilst not to everyonersquos pleasure, was based on an economic impact assessment which has never been revised to reflect the new location and design."Common sense tells you that not a soul will visit Inverness to view this utterly boring creation."He added: "As things stand it appears that as a member of the Inverness city committee, a trustee of the Inverness common good fund and member of the south planning applications committee I, and therefore the people I am elected to represent, have not been involved in the decision-making."Inverness West councillor Bill Boyd, who also sits on the planning committee, said he has written to officers to complain about the way the application has been dealt with.However Councillor Graham Ross, depute provost for Inverness, said it was his understanding that the application had been advertised following normal procedures and had failed to attract enough objections to require it to go to committee."The decision to approve was then taken under delegated powers, which means it met with all the planning regulations," he said.Thursday  Mar  : PM

title: Smoking not wanted at Invernesss Victorian Market
story: Smokers could soon be made unwelcome around the entrances to Invernessrsquos historic Victorian Market as part of a drive to smarten up the appearance of the shopping arcade.The market itself is officially a smoke-free zone, but two letters sent out to traders asking them not to light up around the entrances have had no effect, it was reported at a meeting of the tradersrsquo association recently.Now market manager Jo Murray is investigating whether it would be legal for the smoking bins currently placed at the entrances to be removed in the hope that this will discourage smokers from congregating there.The meeting heard that among the smoking ldquoculprits at the Church Street entrance to the market are patrons of the neighbouring Market Bar, which shares an access close with the Victorian Market.Mrs Murray admitted: ldquoUnfortunately nothing can be done at the Market Bar entrance as it is private.ldquoHowever, I am checking with the fire service to ensure there is no legislation preventing the fire bins at other entrances being removed.ldquoDropped cigarette butts might become a problemthere are no bins, but litter wardens can fine offenders.The tradersrsquo association meeting agreed that removing the smoke bins at the entrances might help improve the image of the market.It was also agreed that all future Victorian Market literature will also declare it a smoke-free zone.Thursday  Mar  : PM

title: inspectors praise staff at aberdeen nursery05
story: Snack time at an Aberdeen nursery is relaxed and sociable, inspectors said.Monitors from the Care Inspectorate watchdog visited Summers Nursery on Victoria Street, Aberdeen, on January  and have now published their report.The nursery can look after up to  children at any one time and inspectors rated it “very good” for care, support and environment – the second best of six possible ratings.“Children’s health and wellbeing was promoted during snack and meal times,” the report said.It added: “We observed these times to be relaxed, sociable experiences, with the pace dictated by each child’s inidual needs.“Staff joined in with children’s conversations, supporting the development of children’s social skills and language development.“They praised and encouraged the children, which helped them to feel safe, protected and included.”

title: work begins on new north east railway station
story: Work has begun to create a new railway station for a north-east town.Kintore Station is the newest addition to the region since , when a site at Laurencekirk was built.Works which started earlier this week are being carried out by Network Rail for the project, with the facility being built beside the B and Northern Road.The project is spearheaded by NESTRANS, Network Rail and Aberdeenshire Council.It forms part of the commitment for the Aberdeen to Inverness line upgrades. When completed, it will mean there will be between three and four peak-hour trains into Aberdeen from both Inverurie and Kintore, and will cut travel time from Aberdeen to Inverness down to two hours.Kintore station has been closed for  years, after being in operation for  years – opening in .Residents have been urged to take part in workshops to develop ideas for potential future artwork, with features that could be included such as soft landscaping and small-scale artist installations leading up to the station.A historic bench, which stood on the site before being lost and then cropping up again at an auction, will also be ed.Nestrans chairman Councillor Peter Argyle said: “Work at Kintore Station began this week with de-vegetation. Following this, the contractors will then be working on establishing their site access and compound.“These are all necessary advance works prior to main construction commencing, which will coincide with the blockade of the line planned this summer.“The final programme from contractors for completion of the project is still being agreed between parties. Nestrans are delighted this milestone has been reached.”Councillor Martin Ford, a long-standing campaigner for the station, said: “After so many years campaigning to get a station built in Kintore, suddenly construction and opening seem very imminent.“At last, work is to begin on site.“It is only a few months now before the structures of the station should be under construction, and only a matter of months after that before the station is due to be finished and then opened.”

title: letters week 06
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSirWe would like to take this opportunity to thank all of those who have either given or offered assistance and support to my family following the fire at our home on the night of January , and a special thanks to the emergency services that attended.Anyone who was present either at the time or who has seen the remains will appreciate the level of destruction wrought upon our home and the contents within, however, as noted in this paper last week, all of us were unharmed and have been provided with accommodation nearby.The support given by friends, work and the wider community has been truly humbling, and as a family we thank you all and look forward to ing to our home, hopefully sometime next year.Thank you,Alan and Gillian Pitman, The Old Church, ArdrishaigSir,I must commend our MP Brendan O#Hara on his vision and wisdom on his recent fact-finding trip to the Faroe Islands to see first hand how The Faroese inter-connect their islands with  subsea and through mountain tunnels.This common sense approach guarantees safe connectivity   in any weather providing confident travel which is the least the people of Mid Argyll, Kintyre, Islay and Jura should expect. This area of Argyll is the most fragile in the region. The people of Argyll, businesses and visitors deserve no less.Forget the squandering of £m on unreliable, mitigation measures trying to justy a flawed decision made many years ago to use the Old Military Road as a ersion which has failed on many occasions and now has a landslip between the two roads. Forget the expensive excavation of pits by the A rather use the cuttings into the hillside to form a two lane road protected with a flow over canopy with closed outer edges at the four problems gullies. If the contractors on the present scheme can work without any road closures then the flow over canopy option would not lead to closures as many officials and some politicians claim.This is a red herring postponing #a proper solution#. When this is option is completed it will save on the expense of manning the ersion route involving - personnel and - vehicles, replacing expensive nettings, delays whilst the farmer clears his animals and collect his fees. A scandalous waste of public money. Solve The Rest Landslides and stop wasting on mitigating measures.Like Brendan O#Hara I#m neither an engineer or geologist but both of us are blessed with plain common sense. If the Faroese can build a tunnel at £.m per kilometre surely a simple open sided m canopy would cost considerably less. In  at Dawlish .km of double tracked railway and .km of sturdy seawall was built at a cost of £m in eight weeks. Why have we in Argyll after nine years, four dferent Transport Ministers and £m spent and still have no guaranteed safe passage   on The Rest and Be Thankful Follow the Argyll Advertiser#s campaign #Invest in the Rest#. Transport Minister Michael Matheson, Transport Scotland and our Government must abandon their obsession with mitigation measures and fund a permanent solution. We demand no less.Sir,Calls for assurances that the Rest and Be Thankful section of the A will be improved to resist future landslides were made during a session of Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity questions in the Scottish Parliament.I quizzed transport secretary Michael Matheson, about what was discussed at the last meeting of the A Taskforce in November , and asked what assurances the Cabinet Secretary could give to local residents and businesses who rely on the A being open at all times.The Rest and Be Thankful was closed off for nine days in October  following the largest landslide in a decade, forcing road users to either take a major ersion, or to use the Old Military Road during certain hours of the day.A number of petitions were created during the period of the incident, including one by myself, calling for a permanent solution to the Rest and Be Thankful.The transport secretary said that the meeting was #full and frank#, and that there would be a #review of the potential for additional landslide mitigation measures at the Rest and Be Thankful#, and that this would be discussed at the next A Taskforce meeting in March .There was also a commitment that Argyll and Bute would be #prioritised# in the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.I welcome the assurances by the transport secretary that there will be a review of any additional measures for the Rest and Be Thankful, and that Argyll and Bute will receive priority at the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.Donald Cameron, MSPReserve forcesSir,Last issue#sletter raising concerns about the UK government’s proposed use of the army’s reserve force in the event of a no-deal Brexit is timely.In case anyone out there still thinks a no-deal Brexit is a good idea it’s worth noting that the legal authorityof Reserve Forces Act  allowing the Secretary of State to take this step requires him to establish that it is necessary #for the alleviation of distress or the preservation of le or property in time of disaster or apprehended disaster#.Enough said.Frances Roberts, Ardrishaig

title: honours even for red star in argyll derby
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowThe Ropework played host to this keenly contested local derby which was watched by a healthy crowd on Saturday February .And for the second time this season, Red Star and Campbeltown Pupils shared the points in a match both sides will feel they could have won.Both sides were struggling for fluency in the opening stages but Red Star settled first and grabbed the opening goal after  minutes. A long ball to the right hand side was met by Ryan Caskie who cut the ball back to Stuart McLean. The youngster took a touch before slotting past the Pupils# goalkeeper to give Star a - lead.Star continued to press and doubled their lead when Coll McCallum robbed the Pupils# defender on the edge of the box before cutting the ball across goal. The unfortunate Pupils# defender could only ert the ball into the empty net, with McLean waiting on a tap in. The game continued at a frantic pace, however, there was no further scoring in the first half and Star went in with a - advantage.Pupils came out with purpose in the second half as they looked to force themselves back into the game, however, it was a howler from Red Star which allowed them back into the match.A square ball across the back resulted in a mix-up between Star keeper Luke Kalache and defender Ben Forbes which allowed Donald McCallum to prod the ball home from just inside the box and Pupils were back in the game at - with eight second half minutes gone.The home side didn’t recover from this and you could sense a nervousness that gave the visitors plenty encouragement. The equaliser arrived with  minutes remaining when good play from Pupils down the right by Soudan saw him get a low cross in which was met by the on-rushing run of Ryan Deans and he finished well to level the score at -.This set up a frantic finish and both sides could have nicked it towards the end. Pupils went close with a headed effort which was clawed to safety while at the other end there was a goalmouth scramble which Star couldn’t convert and both sides had to settle for a draw in the end as referee Jimmy Litster blew for full time.Red Star were dealt a blow as it emerged that captain Aaron Moore suffered a dislocated shoulder. Hopefully this will not keep him out for too long.On Saturday February , Star have another important home game as they look to move off the bottom of the table when they take on Claremont AFC. The game will be played at the Ropework or Joint Campus G # weather permitting # with a pm kick off.

He was a former member of shinty#s South of Scotland area executive council and did a lot of work for the Referees’ Association.He was probably best known for his work with young players in Mid Argyll, organising qualying tournaments of the Aviemore Indoor Sixes tournament for many years. His work for that competition was recognised by the organisers when he was given a special award at Aviemore along with his friend Donnie MacKenzie of Lochaber.John helped reform Kilmory shinty club in the mid s along with Ian MacPhee, the late Kenny MacRae, Roddy Munro and Alex Campbell. He also served on their committee for many years.John had served as a policeman for a short time before working in the quarry at Furnace, then going on to be a very well-known driver with Gleaner Oils, which supported many of his shinty activities with young players in Argyll.John was a great organiser and acted as goal judge in a number of senior shinty finals including the Glasgow Celtic Society Cup and notably the Camanachd Cup Final in Inverness when Gordon MacIntyre of Oban Camanachd scored his famous winner at the Bught Park.John apparently retrieved the ball from the net and lobbed another onto the park for the re-start before presenting the goal-scoring ball to Gordon after the match.John is survived by his brother Jim who played for Glasgow Police and he was pre-deceased by his we Donella. As a couple they were permanent fixtures at most shinty events in Argyll and well beyond, particularly at events involving young players.Tribute reproduced courtesy of the Camanachd Association

title: ayr bids fond farewell military
story: NewsAyr bids fond farewell as military funeral held for soldier Jock McKelvieAyr High Street came to a standstill as Staff Sergeant Jock was taken on his final journey.ShareByAyrshire Post:,  MAR NewsJocks coffin is carried from the Aud Kirk "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAyr came to a reverential standstill for the military funeral of Staff Sergeant John ‘Jock’ McKelvie, writes Edwin Lawrence. Shoppers stopped in their tracks and shopkeepers stood on their doorsteps to honour an Ayrshire soldier. Police sealed off the High Street to cars as the cortege arrived at the Kirk Port entrance to the Auld Kirk. The silence was broken only by the lament of a lone piper as Jock’s family filed their way into church. Jock’s coffin was carried into a packed service by men of the Scottish and North Irish Yeomanry. His coffin was draped in a union flag and on top were his cap, belt, his campaign medals and a wreath. A dozen colleagues in the firing party formed a guard of honour after the coffin had passed under the  lych gate. Jock, , lived in Dundonald with second we Gigliola, better known as Julie. And he ran a log and firewood business, as well as being a yeomanry reservist. He was laid to rest with full military honours at Drongan where he spent his boyhood and where parents Dan and Rita live. The father-of-two died six days after his armoured car overturned at the Catterick Garrison in Yorkshire on January . Among the mourners in the Auld Kirk was Colonel John Dalrymple Hamilton, who was representing Prince Charles. Provost Helen Moonie of South Ayrshire Council also attended the service. And there was military top brass from both regiments in which Jock served –the Royal Scots Dragoon Guards and the Scottish and North Irish Yeomanry. Other regiments represented included the Royal Engineers, the Royal Artillery, the Royal Electrical and Mechanical Engineers and the Le Guards. Members of the Army Cadet Force were also present to pay their respects. Jock was  years in the Royal Scots Dragoon Guards, rising to be a Challenger tank commander. He survived tours of duty in Iraq, Kuwait and Kosovo, only to die in a training exercise. Auld Kirk minister Rev David Gemmell described how John McKelvie ‘grabbed le by the throat’ from his earliest days. He wasn’t much of a scholar at Drongan Primary and Auchinleck Academy, but he knew every creature that ran, crawled, swam or flew in the countryside. And a love of the great outdoors was a huge part of his le – whether it was fishing, playing rugby, ski-ing or mountain biking.  He and we Julie were fond of dogs, and Julie taught her big action man how to ride a horse, said the minister. Major Richard Boyle of the Royal Scots Dragoon Guards read the lesson - ‘To every thing there is a season’ from Ecclesiastes. There were hilarious army anecdotes from best buddy JR Ewing, telling how they had shot at each other - with paintballs. J R also mentioned how when Jock was rebuked by a French officer in Kosovo, the big man pointed to his Royal Scots Dragoon Guards cap badge – a French eagle with the word Waterloo underneath. J R, his voice breaking, concluded by saying: “He was the best soldier I ever served with and my best friend.” Former RSDG officer Will Galbraith highlighted Jock’s pride in his regiment, his family and his friends. He said: “He had a strong sense of honour, of right and wrong, and would always stand up for the underdog.” Will said: “He was a big man, with a big voice and a big heart – a big character. But when you really got to know him, he was a big softie – although you wouldn’t tell him that. You had to be aware of those big hands.” Army chaplain Rev Duncan Macpherson said there were bound to be feelings of frustration, anger and regret at the way John McKelvie died. He hoped these would be resolved, adding: “He was someone who was thoroughly tested, who rose to the challenge and who was a thoroughly professional soldier. He was passionate about vehicles and made sure his was ready for any task.” Lt Colonel Toby Gaddum, commanding officer of the Scottish and North Irish Yeomanry, led the congregation in the regimental prayer. Rev David Gemmell brought the church service to an end by poignantly reciting “We Let You Go’. The poem ends: “We love you, we miss you, we want you to be happy. Go safely, go dancing, go running home.” A collection at the end of the service raised vital cash for the Ayrshire Yeomanry Families Fund. Jock was laid to rest at Drongan Cemetery, where a guard of honour fired three volleys from their rles.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnPrince CharlesRoyal Scots Dragoon GuardsSouth Ayrshire CouncilMiddle EastArmed forcesRoyal FamilyLove and romanceDundonaldAyr NewsAyr

title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a pound, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby

title: college staging wine fuelled feast
story: NewsCollege staging wine-fuelled feast as job cuts loomLeaked emails tell of lavish bash at cash-strapped Ayrshire CollegeShareByStephen Houston:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR News"Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailCollege bosses have defended holding a celebration to honour their success amid a climate of drastic job cuts and cash problems. Ayrshire College supremos and invited senior staff will stage a sit-down feast later this month to mark five years since its formation. The dinner for  will also include free wine after a sponsored deal by college chairman Willie Mackie. Leaked emails state the claim the college is “now regarded as one of the most successful colleges in Scotland.” But our inside source said: “It adds insult to injury that this celebration is being held less than one week before the final jobs structure is issued to staff. “It is in extremely poor taste given the circumstances of potential job losses due to lack of funds.” Evening classes are having to be cancelled so the event can be staged at the Kilmarnock campus on March . Retiring principal Heather Dunk is also to be honoured during the evening. Chairman Willie Mackie said: “She has made a signicant contribution to Ayrshire for over  years.” Ms Dunk retired on February , leaving an impending restructure which will cost jobs. A consultation ends tomorrowand it has emerged the Private Finance Initiative which built the Kilwinning campus is a huge drain on funds. An email which Ms Dunk sent to staff in January read: “We need to make signicant savings to be financially sustainable due to the costs associated with the PFI, unfunded national bargaining costs and the increasing costs of pensions, utilities and other services. I am very disappointed that an organisational review is necessary, it is not what I want to be focused on in my last weeks as principal. “However, we must manage within the financial allocation we receive in this very dficult fiscal climate.” Under the consultation, one of the four vice-principals would be axed, three directors culled, heads of learning cut from  to nine, and three marketing coms staff would go. Also at risk of the chop are two posts within estates as well as a shake-up of duties among departments. The board of management will approve the final structure and staff impacted will get a severance package. Ayrshire College acknowledged finance was a major challenge for all Scottish colleges but said the dinner costs were met by sponsorship. A spokeswoman said: “Our main financial challenge for the year ahead is to meet the costs associated with the Kilwinning PFI Campus, national bargaining costs and the increasing costs of pensions, utilities and services. “While the Scottish Funding Council has agreed to provide further strategic funds to help manage these rising costs, the college still requires to make signicant savings to secure its financial sustainability and jobs for the future. “We are, therefore, considering proposals for an organisational review. “All staff are aware of the challenges the college faces, and have contributed to a consultation regarding potential efficiencies and opportunities for income generation. “We have just passed our five-year anniversary as Ayrshire College, and have planned an event, ‘Celebrating Five Years of Success. It is important to recognise this milestone and celebrate success – for learners, staff, the college and the region. “We are mindful of the costs of holding such an event and so have secured full sponsorship.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnUniversities and CollegesAyr NewsAyrEducationKilmarnockSchoolsKilwinning

The Royal National Leboat InstitutionAyr branch announced their closure after it struggled to keep afloat. The branch, which has been around for over  years, issued an urgent appeal last November, appealing for a younger generation to pitch in to save the Ayr branch . Committee member and Secretary Robin White, said: “Sadly the number of volunteers helping to run the branch recently has been dwindling, to such an extent that so few are left the AGM came to the sad decision to close the branch down. However, a number of branch members have indicated they still wish to support the RNLI and will now do so via the Troon Branch. “This Branch is looking for new volunteers, soyou would like to help, please get in touch.” Ayr once had its own Leboat, stationed at Ayr Harbour in  under the management of Ayr Harbour Trust.   During the following  years a number of dferent Leboats were in service, one of which was built in Shadwell, London in  for just under pound. This was transported from London to Ayr Station by rail free of charge, by the London and North Western Railway Company. It was taken down Ayr High Street to Ayr Harbour and christened the ‘Janet Hoyle’, after the donor’s we. Eventually in  the RNLI Committee of Management decided to close the station as Troon had a motor Leboat where there was deemed a safer harbour entrance. There was then no RNLI presence in the town until the late ’s when a group of people decided to start a Fundraising Branch. This has been in existence ever since and has raised well over pound, in its time.

title: giant bins placed right outside
story: NewsGiant bins placed right outside a restaurant and pub in scenic townAnger in Troon as bin squad set up town corral without asking anyone for permissionShareByStephen Houston:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR News "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA council works gang put up a new big bin enclosure – right outside a restaurant and pub in the scenic centre of town. Now a row has broken out after it emerged one council department had not even bothered to speak to another. The unsightly corral cluster for five bins was secured in place near The Cross in Troon without any consultation. Troon Councillors have now become aware after a multitude of complaints. The cleansing department is claiming they contacted the planning department about the placing of the bins. But planners are denying any knowledge of a consultation. Troon SNP Councillor Craig Mackay is now leading the charge to find somewhere  for the bins to be situated, rather than outside the Jade Garden Chinese and Macintyre’s bar. He is asking for officials to meet councillors at the spot in Templehill to try and find a resolution. Councillor Mackay said: “We are trying to develop a coherent vision for our town centre. “I’m not convinced this is the best we can manage for such a high profile location. Cleansing regrettably installed these enclosures without any prior consultation. While it is arguably an operational matter that doesn’t require any such input,they had asked any of the councillors or the community council for comment then I am certain we would not have found ourselves in this situation. “The council’s Planning service disappointingly also appear not to have been consulted on the siting or design of this bin store within the conservation area. I don’t wish to play departments off against each other, but would seek to find a community consensus about what is appropriate for our public realm. “This will almost certainly involve an alternative solution for the bins.” A council spokesman confirmed they are investigating, saying: ““We introduced communal bins to keep the litter secure and away from gulls. The early indications are that this system is working well, however we are currently reviewing the location of the bins.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnScottish National PartyTroonAyrAyr News

story: NewsLook out, Sooty and Sweep are heading to AyrStage show insists laughs will come thick and fast at Ayr GaietyShareByStephen Houston:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR News "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailSooty is set to SWEEP into Ayr next month. The wee silent man will be on stage with his squeeky pal Sweep and chatterbox Soo. TheirRichard Cadell will lead events at The Gaiety in Ayr on April . It’s being billed as a brand new Laugh Out Loud Magic Show. Sooty takes to the air in a flying car, Soo has a singing unicorn and Sweep has something altogether dferent. He has a levitating sausage, which certainly creates a vision. Special guests circus star Michael Jordan and the ultraviolet specialties of Fantasie de la Nuit promise a thrilling -minute show. Tickets are between pound and pound and there are two shows – am and .pm. Sooty has celebrated his th birthday and Richard says he’s still as young as ever. Richard revealed: “This show is Sooty doing what he does best – magic. “So the Gaiety audience can expect to be saying ‘Izzy whizzy let’s get busy’ a great deal. “Sooty will be performing some amazing tricks including sawing a lady in half, floating a child from the audience and making it snow. “Sweep will be getting in the way with his own disastrous magic tricks most of which revolve around sausages.” He added: “Performing live is what we love most. story: NewsTributes to Cumnocks footballing legend CaldowDeath of Eric Caldow, aged ShareByStephen Houston:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsHero - Eric on parade at the UEFA Cup semi at Ibrox  years ago "Get the biggest Rangers stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAyrshire footballing great Eric Caldow died peacefully on Monday morning. He was . The former Rangers and Scotland captain had been enjoying the final stage of his le at the Burnfoot Care home in Patna. The defender played  times for the national team,  of them as captain. Eric’s daughter Jacqueline McTaggart, , said: “It is still sinking in. “He was known as a gentleman on the pitch and that was exactly what he was off the pitch. The whole family is very proud of Dad.” Eric was born in Cumnock and attended Cumnock Academy. After leaving school he became an apprentice painter with Cumnock Burgh Council. It was with Glenpark Amateurs then Muirkirk in the Western Junior League that his career was shaped. Eric was in the famous Gers team as they took their first steps into European competition in the s. He captained the side in the - European Cup Winners’ Cup final against Fiorentina. He won six titles as manager and the Treble in   was the crowning glory when a side that still trips off the tongues of many supporters. It was Ritchie Shearer, Caldow Greig, McKinnon, Baxter Henderson, McMillan, Millar, Brand  Wilson. He played  times for Rangers between  and , scoring  goals, and won five League Championships, two Scottish Cups and three League Cups. Eric won his first full Scotland international cap against England in  in a - defeat at Wembley. In , he suffered a broken leg in three places during a - win for Scotland at Wembley. The injury cut short his international career. John Greig, Rangers honorary le president and former teammate, said: “Eric was a great player and captain for the club, but above all  he was an absolute gentleman. “The biggest compliment you can give Eric is that a lot of people outside the club, when they saw him, would say, ‘That’s Eric Caldow of Rangers’.” Eric’s we Laura died six years ago. title: intriguing-new-additions-for-the-sir-walter-collection-at-abbotsford
story: NEW additions are being included to the intriguing Sir Walter Scott exhibition at Abbotsford.A wooden Jacobite quaich, a rare pack of th century playing cards, a slop bowl and a Persian charm are among a range of new items added to the exhibition, which went on show from Friday.The Jacobite quaich belonged to Sir Walterrsquos great grandfather, Walter lsquoBeardiersquo Scott.Beardie fought for the Jacobite cause and famously vowed not to trim his beard until a Stuart monarch regained the throne.Also new to the exhibition is a copy of Adam Smithrsquos Wealth of Nations, which Scott used as a student at Edinburgh University.Visitors only have a limited time to see a gold memorial locket, set with semi-precious stones spelling out the author name as an acrostic poem.The piece will be ing to the private lender in May, alongside a silver centrepiece commemorating the th anniversary of Scottrsquos poem The Lady of the Lake.Kirsty Archer-Thompson, Abbotsfordrsquos collections and interpretation manager, said: ldquoOur introductory exhibition to the le and legacy of Sir Walter Scott is refreshed every year, so there is always something new for visitors to see.ldquoThis year we have added an extensive mix of items ranging from family heirlooms and some of Scottrsquos favourite books, to more exotic items like the Persian amulet.ldquoWe are also looking forward to making further changes this year, when we will be loaned an exciting range of items from the National Museum of Scotland later in the Spring, so itrsquos worth people coming back for another look in a few months.The free exhibition will be open daily to visitors from March .Visitors can go see the exhibition from am to pm.

title: campaigners-call-time-on-single-use-pint-pots-at-borders-events
story: CAMPAIGNERS are calling for pint pot deposit schemes at public events in the Scottish Borders.Tom Rawson of Plastic Free Melrose said the group is fighting to cut back on plastic use in the town.And one of the suggestions is to get revellers to buy a re-useable cup at gatherings such as the Rugby Sevens tournament.At the local community council meeting last week, he said: ldquoPlastic usage is a huge issue everywhere.ldquoAnd I think it is embarrassing as a society that we have such a problem.ldquoWe want to look at stopping this problem. One of the ways is by going into local businesses to encourage them to cut down on what they use.ldquoAn idea we have also had is introducing a pint deposit scheme, similar to the one which is in place at Murrayfield.ldquoThat is something we could look at bringing to Melrose at events such as the Rugby Sevens to cut down on single use plastic. Everyone pays for one pint pot and it is reused, rather than just thrown away.The Scottish Government is also currently shaping a lsquodepositschemersquo for drinks containers following positive feedback in a public consultation.If brought in, it would see consumers reclaim a percentage of the cost of every plastic bottle they recycle.A similar scheme has also been introduced in Norway.Val Miller, vice chairwoman of Melrose Community Council said: ldquoPlastic Free Melrose can take our support as a given.ldquoThere is so much plastic these days. Most of what you buy in the supermarket is pre-packed, no matter how much you try to get away from it.Campaigners have also been working with local schoolchildren to teach them about plastic pollution.And the group recently organised a litter pick around the town.Mr Rawson said: ldquoThe issue needs to be stopped at its source.ldquoIf your bath is overflowing, you donrsquot just pull the plug out ndash you turn the taps off. That is how we can change things, by encouraging people not to use as much.

title: bus-passenger-ordered-to-pay-compensation
story: A -year-old who was abusive towards a bus driverhas been ordered to pay a total of pound at Selkirk Sherf Court.Richard Tindall of Gala Park Gardens, Galashiels, was fined pound for behaving in a threatening or abusive manner on board the bus in Abbotsford Road, Galashiels, on June .And he was told to pay pound compensation to the driver.A video of the incident was played in the courtroom which showed Tindall abusing the driver and then after leaving the bus re-boarded to continue the onslaught.A female passenger was heard to protest when Tindall said, get out this country and go back to where you came from among other obscenities.Procurator fiscal Graham Fraser said there was no screen guarding the drivers compartment so he was a sitting duck in his seat.He continued: "The accused was trying to get off the bus and there was a dispute about the fare."He was trying to force open the doors in the company of his young daughter at the time."He was using words such as scumbag, idiot and stick it up your a***."As the video shows the accused came back on the bus to continue the abuse."People should not be exposed to this kind of behaviour in the course of their employment."Defence lawyer Joe Boyd described it as an unsavoury incident.He explained that his client had got on the bus with his young daughter who had immediately ran up to the back of the bus which had annoyed the driver.Mr Boyd said that Tindall had suffered a traumatic brain injury in October  which sometimes causes him to react to situations.He said: "He can be the most pleasant of characters but the next minute he can descend into something of the opposite."

title: folk-stars-megan-and-findlay-bring-science-to-hawick
story: ITS one of the most anticipated releases in folk music.And for a sneak preview of Megan Henwood and Findlay Napiers The Story Song Scientist, they will play in the Borders.Back in , Megan won the BBC Young Folk Award, aged just , alongside her brother Joe.Since then, she has gone on to become a formidable British talent.And in  she embarked on her first sold-out headline UK tour ahead of her third and finest album to date lsquoRiverrsquo.More recently though Megan has teamed up with one of the finest songwriters and storytellers of the contemporary Scottish folk scene.Findlay Napier is an insurgent talent who made his name touring and recording with multi-award winning traditional Scottish folk band Back of the Moon.In his more recent projects his song-writing took centre stage and was described by The Sunday Herald as genuine songcraft and wit following in the Dford  Tilbrook tradition.Findlay is also well known as the host of Celtic Connectionsrsquo Late Night Sessions and for his Hazy Recollections concert series which showcases the very best in new roots music.Megan and Findlay met a songwriting retreat in  in Aldeburgh, Suffolk, run by the English Folk and Dance Song Society and co-wrote some songs together which resulted in the forthcoming EP.The Story Song Scientist will be released on Dharma Records on March .And just a few days earlier - Monday, March  to be precise - they will play together at the String Theory club night in Hawick.Ticketsare available on the door.

title: pentlands-activity-camps-is-looking-for-volunteers
story: This weekrsquos feature from Tweeddale Volunteers focuses on volunteer opportunities for older teenagers ndash at Pentlands Activity Camps.Wanted: volunteers age +... Want to spend your holidays in the great outdoors, learning new skills and having fun Pentlands Activity Camps offers multi-activity and specialist day camps for school age children during the holidays ndash based in the woods and fields of Netherurd and Broomlee, local outdoor centres.Established in , PAC offers older teenagersand young adults the opportunity to develop work and le skills with children by volunteering as an assistant leader at one of our camps.Your role would be to support a group leader to plan, organise and lead a iety of outdoor and indoor activities ndash anything from playing lsquokick the canrsquo to building dens in the woods, junk boat racing to capture the flag, rounders to baking.
